bibl.title: Letter from Frederick L. Rath, Jr., to Maria Teresa Rojas, March 5, 1952

div1.p: Rath discusses his recent lunch with Hench, and provides Rojas with information about the National Trust for Historic Preservation. He has been unable to obtain information about preservation activities in Cuba, but will continue to search.

div1.head: Letter from Frederick L. Rath, Jr., to Maria Teresa Rojas, March 5, 1952
div1.opener:
March 5, 1952
Senora Maria Teresa Rojas
Quinta San Jose
Calzado Real
Quemados de Marianas
Cuba
Dear Senora Rojas:
div1.p:
Last week it was my very great pleasure to have luncheon as
well as a long talk with Dr. Philip S. Hench, of Mayo Clinic. We dis-
cussed at some length his recent visit to Cuba and his tremendous
interest in the development of the yellow fever campsite in Quemados.
Dr. Hench said that you might wish to know something about our work
in the field of historic preservation in the States, so I am taking the
liberty of writing to you and sending information about our work.

The national organizations which I represent are relatively
new: The National Council for Historic Sites and Buildings is only five
years old, the National Trust for Historic Preservation only two and a
half years old, but each is beginning to take an important part in the
work of historical preservation here. Especially important is the
National Trust, for it has been chartered by the Congress of the United
States as a private, non-Governmental society to accept, hold, and
administer sites, buildings and objects significant in American history
and culture. Like the English National Trust, with which you may be
familiar, it is prepared, when necessary and desirable, to assure the
continued preservation of physical remains of our heritage.

We have made inquiries in Washington about the present situa-
tion in Cuba, but thus far we have obtained no concrete information in
regard to your nation's activities in the field of preservation. We shall
continue our search and possibly we shall learn something of value. In
the meantime it is our hope that the history of our effort here will
Senora Rojas
-2-
March 5, 1952
stimulate your interest. If there is any further information that you wish
to have about the nature of our activity, please do not hesitate to write.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours Frederick L. Rath, Jr.
